channel.title: English Editorial Combined Feed
channel.description: Aggregated English editorial feed without duplicates

item.title: The Case for Gradual Population Decline
item.description: Contrary to conventional wisdom, rapid population growth rarely delivers demographic dividends, while low fertility rates do not necessarily lead to stagnation. In fact, persistently high fertility often exacerbates underemployment, limits investment in education and infrastructure, and entrenches poverty across generations.

item.title: Essential India Newsletter: What Britain can learn from Aadhaar
item.description: Leo Mirani, our Asia correspondent, considers the lessons from 15 years of India’s digital-ID system

item.title: Will an Upper House solve Bangladesh’s governance woes?
item.description: Bicameralism and proportional representation are not the panacea to solve all our problems of abuse of power.

item.title: Silenced families of Bangladesh and Gaza
Govt should step up anti-trafficking efforts
Kazakhstan’s Digital Crossroad
item.description: To reduce its reliance on Russia’s internet ecosystem, Kazakhstan has invested significant sums in upgrading its infrastructure and developing international transit capabilities. But becoming a digital hub will ultimately depend on whether the government loosens its regulatory hold on the internet.

item.title: Is Bangladesh prepared to face quake consequence?
Must Our Globalized World Be a Suicide Pact?
item.description: Silicon Valley pitchmen would like us to believe that technology will determine the future. But the more important variable is whether and how our institutions adapt, a matter that remains entirely within our power to decide – at least for now.

item.title: Business
The weekly cartoon
Politics
Latin America’s Structural Crisis
item.description: Decades of sluggish growth, premature deindustrialization, and insufficient investment have left Latin American countries dependent on commodity exports and vulnerable to external shocks. To avoid another lost decade, governments must adopt bold industrial policies, deepen regional integration, and focus on job creation.

item.description: US President Donald Trump advanced a peace proposal that essentially preserves Israeli pre-eminence regarding the fate of Palestinians

item.title: The Making or Breaking of Democracy
item.description: The rise of authoritarian leaders like US President Donald Trump shows that too many of us took democracy, and the prosperity it generates, for granted. Now, a growing movement of democratic countries is coming together to push back on the dangerous trend that Trump represents.

Open manholes and crisis of accountability
Green cities, resilient future
Mexico Must End Cash Dependence
item.description: Mexico’s cash-heavy economy leaves it vulnerable to tax evasion, corruption, and money laundering. By emulating successful electronic-payment platforms in emerging markets like Brazil and India, policymakers could foster financial inclusion, boost government revenues, and stabilize public finances.

item.title: Trump’s Gaza plan is a weak foundation for peace
item.description: The proposal offers a pause in bloodshed, but its unilateral terms show glaring weaknesses

UNGA Resolution 2758 brooks no challenge and Taiwan's sovereignty is unquestionable
Bangladesh charts a course for shipbuilding excellence
Your federal government is now closed for business
item.description: The short- and longer-term consequences of another governing fail in Washington

item.title: Trump’s Beggar-the-Poor Remittance Tax
item.description: Remittance inflows to low-income countries have improved welfare, reduced poverty, and enhanced economic resilience. But with the Trump administration’s 1% tax on remittances threatening to erode these benefits, the developing world must address the underlying causes of brain drain and pursue technology-led growth.

item.title: The World of Yesterday
item.description: For decades, Europeans have been deeply attached to the idea of the transatlantic West, and to an image of America as a bastion of freedom, democracy, and security. But that description increasingly sounds like an echo from a bygone age.

item.title: Why the Working Class Matters
item.description: For the Western left, the lesson of the last decade is agonizingly clear. To focus exclusively on identity – on race and gender – while ignoring the material reality of class and repudiating the working class itself, is a catastrophic strategic error.

item.title: How Asia Can Reduce Its Dollar Dependence
item.description: Despite heightened geopolitical tensions and escalating trade wars, the US dollar’s global dominance is unlikely to fade in the near term. This leaves Asian economies vulnerable to dollar shocks, underscoring the need for deeper regional cooperation and stronger financial safety nets.

item.title: On Climate Change, Capital Must Follow Africa’s Lead
item.description: With its vast solar resources and rapidly growing population, Africa has the potential to achieve a green transition that delivers sustainable and inclusive growth. But achieving this will require closing a $2.8 trillion financing shortfall by mobilizing international capital for African-led initiatives.

item.title: A New Paradigm for Financing Education
item.description: In addition to replenishing global financial support for education, developing countries also need a new strategy to establish self-sustaining education systems that can deliver consistent quality for all children. To that end, the issue should be at the center of all national development plans.

item.title: Davos for Diplomats
item.description: The United Nations is now 80, and its long slide toward irrelevance appears unstoppable. The design of the Security Council has become a recipe for paralysis, but that is only the start of the organization's problems.
